Key Arguments: The legislation represents a concerning overreach and mandates censorship of Australian citizens.
The Bill is based on pandemic-specific research with small cohorts, which is insufficient for such significant legislation.
The definition of 'harm' in the Bill is overly broad and politically motivated.
The Bill could lead to further mistrust in government and drive misinformation to less scrutinized areas.
The Bill empowers tech companies with a history of bias and censorship.
The concept of misinformation is tied to agreement with government positions rather than objective truth.
The legislation could be weaponized for political purposes.
Notable Quotes: The Bill is founded upon pandemic-specific research with woefully small cohorts that ought not to be the foundation for a political, ideological tilt towards silencing open discussion of issues in this country by its populace.
The Bill offers a definition of 'harm' that moves well beyond any possible sensible interpretation of that word.
The predictable and inevitable impact of this Bill and its implementation, if passed, will only be to lower institutional trust further.

The concept of controlling misinformation in the way being encouraged here has been well tested through propaganda of the past and the results for the citizens of those countries have always been bad.
